Meet our Siemens Top Innovator for 2025!

Congratulations again, Charley Selvidge! üéâ 

Thanks for helping me make the surprise happen,and. This was fun.

The future of American manufacturing is bright ‚Äì especially when we connect the brilliance of academia with the scale and speed of industry. 

That was the spirit of my visit toin Boston this week. In every conversation, it was clear: MIT andshare a deep commitment to shaping the future of manufacturing through adaptive production. Why this kind of collaboration matters:

1Ô∏è‚É£ It accelerates innovation: Ideas move from lab to production faster, where they can be tested, scaled and put to work on the factory floor.

2Ô∏è‚É£ It shapes tomorrow‚Äôs talent: By combining academic excellence with real-world experience, people gain the skills needed to lead the next manufacturing era.

3Ô∏è‚É£ It expands what‚Äôs possible: From software-defined automation to flexible factories, innovation thrives when disciplines converge.

I‚Äôm proud that Siemens is a founding member of the MIT Initiative for New Manufacturing, contributing $1.5 million to help drive AI in production, advance next-gen technologies and empower the workforce of the future.

Thank you to Professorfor the inspiring exchange and thank you to Professorfor a great conversation on the promise of adaptive production ‚Äì more to come soon!

It‚Äôs time for Europe to accelerate and lead!

While others are scaling industrial AI at lightning speed, Europe is running the risk of falling behind. In China, industrial foundation models are already deployed backed by strong political support and an aligned ecosystem. In Europe, fragmented markets and heavy regulations slow AI adoption. But it doesn‚Äôt have to stay that way.

This week, I joined 70+ leaders for the launch of the's Leaders for European Growth and Competitiveness initiative. One message was clear: Europe can lead the world in industrial AI; if we act now and act together. We have everything it takes to lead: the industrial base, rich operational data, engineering and software expertise.

So, what‚Äôs next? Here are three priorities:
üëâ Unite our industrial know-how in powerful ecosystems
üëâ Share data openly wherever it makes sense
üëâ Simplify regulation to scale fast

At, we‚Äôre all in. I‚Äôm proud to bring our perspective to this group and push for real outcomes. Let‚Äôs stop talking about potential.

Let‚Äôs start building Europe‚Äôs next chapter together.

Welcome to Siemens, Vasi Philomin! üòä We‚Äôre excited to have you on board - and to shape the future of industrial AI together.

Vasi joins us from, where he led AWS‚Äôs generative AI product strategy. At, he will take on the role of Executive Vice President and Head of our new Data & Artificial Intelligence department. He‚Äôll play a key role in scaling our AI capabilities - from growing our portfolio of 35+ AI-powered applications to developing an industrial foundation model that delivers industrial-grade AI for our customers.

With his deep expertise in AI, machine learning, and platform architecture, Vasi is a fantastic addition to
. Great to have you with us! üëè

From a snow-covered village in Switzerland to a buzzing coastal city in China: this is what makes the World Economic Forum so unique.

This week, I joined the summer edition of the WEF in Tianjin. The backdrop couldn‚Äôt be more different from Davos, but the depth of insight, the energy and the sense of urgency were just as strong.

My three highlights:

üéôÔ∏è On stage, we discussed how industrial AI is moving fast everywhere around the world. To stay competitive, we must not only go fast but match this speed with precision and trust.

üß†is proud to be part of the WEF‚Äôs MINDS program. This is a great opportunity to bring real industrial use cases to the table and ensure AI doesn‚Äôt just stay in the lab, but delivers real-world value.

üéì Alongside the Forum, I met with students at Guanghua School of Management. Their curiosity and thoughtful questions were a great reminder that exchange and collaboration matter at every level ‚Äì across governments, industries and generations.

Let‚Äôs keep the conversation going. Let‚Äôs keep learning from each other. And let‚Äôs build industrial AI that drives progress.

Every time we breathe in, our immune system quietly goes to work, fighting off threats, adapting and keeping us strong. Imagine if industries had the same kind of protection. With Artificial Intelligence, we can build this kind of digital immune system ‚Äì designed not just to detect threats, but to adapt, learn and grow stronger over time. But unlike biology, we have to build it from the ground up.

In today‚Äôs fast-moving digital world, getting it right matters. We need systems that are resilient, responsive and ready for anything. This is where industrial AI comes in‚Ä¶ Read more in myarticle:

The pace of change in Southeast Asia is striking. 

From smart grids to semiconductors to state-of-the-art factories ‚Äì transformation is happening in real time. I had the pleasure of experiencing this firsthand during my trip to Indonesia and Vietnam last week.

Here are three reflections that stood out to me:

‚û°Ô∏è Speed matters. The region is racing ahead and laying the groundwork for the future at an unprecedented pace.

‚û°Ô∏è Local talent drives global impact. Our teams understand what matters to customers and deliver with precision.

‚û°Ô∏è Collaboration is the engine of transformation. At our Jakarta tech event, nearly 600 partners and customers joined us to discuss how technology can enable a smarter, more sustainable future for Indonesia. I was also proud to witness the signing of two Memorandums of Understanding and a new partnership with four leading universities.

In Southeast Asia, it‚Äôs not just speed for speed‚Äôs sake. It‚Äôs about turning momentum into lasting impact. And we athave the right technology, skills and expertise to make that happen.

What do you remember from 2006? The launch of Twitter? Angela Merkel hitting her stride as Germany‚Äôs first female chancellor? The first viral videos on YouTube like ‚ÄúThe Evolution of Dance‚Äù? At the time I was finishing my PhD ‚Äì on globalization and how to adapt to low-cost competition. The news was packed with headlines on the threat Asian competitors posed to markets in Western Europe and the US.

That‚Äôs still the case today. What‚Äôs changed is that we‚Äôre playing an entirely different game...

I welcome the Commission‚Äôs new push to help startups scale across Europe. 

Reducing red tape, enabling one European operation instead of 27, and unlocking more venture capital are the right priorities.

With our Siemens for Startups program, we‚Äôre supporting this momentum ‚Äì by empowering founders, connecting them to markets, and collaborating to bring innovation to scale.

Boston has long been a global hub for innovation ‚Äì and with the launch of Massachusetts Institute of Technology‚Äôs Initiative for New Manufacturing (INM), it‚Äôs strengthening its role in advancing the future of manufacturing with partners like. As a Founding Member, we are proud to deepen our work with MIT to drive AI in production, accelerate next-gen technologies, and strengthen workforce skills ‚Äì all essential to U.S. manufacturing resilience.

We‚Äôre contributing $1.5 million to support cutting-edge research and training, bringing real-world use cases into joint projects, and co-developing programs to prepare engineers and leaders ‚Äì including within Siemens ‚Äì for a digital future.

With over 80 joint research projects since 2008, this new chapter builds on a strong and proven foundation. And for me, it‚Äôs also a personal one: having lived and worked in Boston, I‚Äôve seen firsthand the power of its innovation ecosystem and the impact of close collaboration between academia and industry.

This is about real progress ‚Äì for industry, for people, and for the future of manufacturing in the U.S.

Read more here:

;;;;;

We talk too much about risks and too little about opportunities.

In Germany, our instinct is often to hesitate. The first thing we tend to ask in business discussions is ‚ÄúWho is liable?‚Äù instead of ‚ÄúWhat is possible?‚Äù If we want to stay competitive, we need to shift that mindset from hesitation to innovation.

Because while we‚Äôre worrying about the risks of new technologies, others are already capturing the benefits. The good news: We have what it takes to turn this around. Germany has a strong industrial basis, global leadership in many sectors like pharmaceuticals, automotive or electronics and access to vast amounts of industrial data. Now it‚Äôs up to all of us, in business, politics and society, to turn this potential into progress.

At theeSummit in Berlin, I shared what it takes to make this happen:

‚úÖ Boost productivity. Germany‚Äôs growth potential for 2025 is just 0.8‚ÄØ%. In the U.S., it‚Äôs more than twice that. One way to close that gap is by unlocking the value of industrial data ‚Äì 80 % of which remains unused today.

‚úÖ A political environment that prioritizes innovation over regulation. This is the mindset shift I have already mentioned. Let‚Äôs embrace the many opportunities technology offers.

‚úÖ Build AI applications. New data centers and AI models alone won‚Äôt do the trick. What matters is how we apply AI to generate real value on the factory floor, in infrastructure and mobility.

This isn‚Äôt something Germany can achieve alone. We‚Äôre part of a strong European ecosystem. This is a strategic moment for all of us. What we need now is alignment. It‚Äôs time to stop debating and start building our future together.

Industrial AI is more than just technology. It‚Äôs a cultural shift in how we work, how we produce and how we lead.

Germany has reinvented itself before. We can do it again by embracing opportunity and making industrial AI the driver of our next transformation.

Photos ¬©ZVEI/Munir Werner

Does Europe still have what it takes to be a global leader? 

It absolutely does ‚Äì now more than ever. 

Europe has a unique opportunity to shape the next chapter of industrial innovation by unlocking its superpower: industrial AI. The kind of AI that makes machines smarter, factories more efficient and workers more empowered.

Yesterday, at the AI with Purpose Summit, I shared three steps on how Europe can access this superpower:

üîç Focus ‚Äì Europe already leads in industrial software, industrial AI and the industrial metaverse. We have deep industrial domain expertise and a vast treasure trove of industrial data.  Now is the time to turn that heritage into a competitive advantage.

üîß Transform ‚Äì To lead in industrial AI, we must transform the way we work with it. At Siemens, we‚Äôre doing just that: with our Industrial Copilot, AI agents and the first industrial foundation model that speaks the language of engineering.

ü§ù Collaborate ‚Äì Europe is not a lone superhero. We‚Äôre a team of Avengers. Sharing high-quality, contextualized data is how we can make a huge impact. It makes industrial AI more accurate, scalable and useful for everyone.

Now let‚Äôs turn momentum into action. Let‚Äôs join forces and create industrial AI made in Europe ‚Äì for the world.

Der Besuch des ehemaligen Konzentrationslagers Auschwitz im Januar hat mich tief bewegt und ber√ºhrt. Dort habe ich am Gedenken zum 80. Jahrestag der Befreiung teilgenommen.

Heute, am 8. Mai 2025, j√§hrt sich nun das Ende des Zweiten Weltkriegs in Europa zum 80. Mal ‚Äì letztlich ist das die Geburtsstunde des heutigen, freien Europas. Aber an diesem Tag erinnern wir uns zun√§chst vor allem an die Millionen von Menschen, die in den Jahren zuvor verfolgt, entrechtet und ermordet wurden. Der heutige Jahrestag mahnt uns zu reflektieren, wie es zu diesen Verbrechen kommen konnte ‚Äì und welche Verantwortung daraus f√ºr uns heute entsteht.

Gemeinsam mit vielen anderen CEOs deutscher Unternehmen bekennen wir uns zu der historischen Verantwortung, die sich auch aus unserer Unternehmensgeschichte ergibt. Wir verpflichten uns, die Erinnerung an die Verbrechen des Nationalsozialismus wachzuhalten. F√ºr uns ist klar: Einen Schlussstrich darf und wird es nicht geben. Die Verbrechen der Nationalsozialisten mahnen uns, die Zerbrechlichkeit der Demokratie zu erkennen. Demokratie ger√§t immer dann in Gefahr, wenn ihre Grundwerte und Institutionen ausgeh√∂hlt werden, wenn politische Gegner oder gesellschaftliche Gruppen zu Feinden erkl√§rt werden, wenn Gewalt geduldet und eingesetzt wird, um b√ºrgerliche Freiheiten einzuschr√§nken.

Demokratie lebt von Engagement, von Widerspruch und vom Mut, Haltung zu zeigen. Deshalb setzen wir uns gemeinsam mit anderen Unternehmen f√ºr eine lebendige Erinnerungskultur ein ‚Äì und stellen uns klar gegen Antisemitismus, Hass und Ausgrenzung.

,,,

Industry is at a crossroads and it‚Äôs the road paved with AI that will take us into the future. At HANNOVER MESSE we showed again how technology can help our customers hit the accelerator. My personal highlights: 

üí° The evolution of our Siemens Industrial Copilot. It was a very proud moment for us all to receive the Hermes Award for it this year.

üí° AI agents showcased at our booth ‚Äì for example one we‚Äôre developing with the Engineering company. It will empower factories to update themselves, saving automation engineers lots of time.

üí° Our end-to-end showcase demonstrates how combining the real and the digital worlds can help develop new medications much faster and make the factories that produce them much more efficient and sustainable.

üí° The industrial foundation model we‚Äôre working on. It speaks the languages of engineering and will help AI reach its full potential in industry.

A special thanks tofrom Microsoft who joined me for a great discussion on the future of AI. And a big thank you to my fellow speakers on the Digital Transformation Stage:(AWS),(NVIDIA) and(3M). Strong partnerships like these are what we need to realize the full potential of AI and the industrial metaverse.

Finally, a big shout out to ourbooth team! You do an amazing job making everything run smoothly!

This week I had the pleasure of visiting my colleagues in Australia! One of the first topics that came up? Formula 1. Not only because Melbourne‚Äôs own Oscar Piastri recently won the Chinese Grand Prix, but also because F1 is evolving ‚Äì just like industries worldwide ‚Äì as it moves towards a more sustainable future.

During my trip, I had inspiring discussions with colleagues, customers, public stakeholders, and academics about what it takes to decarbonize Australia. One thing became clear: There‚Äôs no single solution, but many different paths to a more sustainable future.

What really stood out to me is how the path to decarbonization requires the same strengths that make a Formula 1 team successful: precision, speed, and smart decision-making. Just like in racing, where every millisecond and move counts, driving real impact with technology means bringing together the right people, tools, and insights. Whether it‚Äôs using digital twins to prepare our energy grids for the renewable transition, applying AI to conserve vital resources like water, or designing entire factories in the industrial metaverse ‚Äì none of it happens in isolation. It takes a team. And at Siemens, we know what it takes to collaborate across disciplines and borders. Because collaboration is what drives innovation.

A big thank you to all my colleagues in Australia and New Zealand for enabling our customers and partners in the region contribute to a more sustainable future. It was wonderful to meet so many of you, exchange perspectives, and dive into the challenges and opportunities ahead!

Innovation is at the heart of everything we do at Siemens. Being recognized as Europe‚Äôs top patent applicant once again underscores our commitment to shaping the future with cutting-edge technology. These patents are more than just numbers ‚Äì they represent groundbreaking ideas that drive industrial transformation and create real impact. A big thank you to our brilliant teams for turning innovation into reality!

Image Source:

How do we turn AI into real-world impact? By bringing it where it matters most: industry.

AI is already transforming industries, but the real game-changer? Collaboration. That‚Äôs why Siemens is expanding the AI ecosystem with the Industrial AI Awards for Startups!

üîç Are you a startup based in Europe using AI to solve industrial challenges? Then we are looking for you. We want to see how your AI solutions are shaping the future of industry!

Find out more about how to apply and what‚Äôs in for you here:

Let‚Äôs build a smarter, better world together.

How quickly can technology transform a nation? What does it take to harness AI in the public and private sectors? And what are the challenges? The UAE has turned itself into a testbed for all these questions. In 2017, it was the first country to create a ministry for Artificial Intelligence and publish a dedicated AI strategy. Today, you‚Äôll find AI-enhanced solutions improving efficiency in everything from wastewater networks to energy grids to steel plants. And there is a strong commitment to create more sustainable communities and use technologies like AI to improve people‚Äôs lives. We heard about some fantastic examples at TransformMENA in Dubai last week, and it was a pleasure to connect with colleagues from the region and with representatives from business and government.

But among all the great discussions, my main takeaway was this: Technology alone is not enough. You need a strong foundation built on utilizing industrial data, seamless technology adoption and open ecosystems. And, even more importantly, you need a cultural shift ‚Äì you need your people to be on board.
Speaking of people: At ouroffice in Dubai, I met remarkable female leaders and rising talents who are shaping the future of the region. Their stories demonstrate that diversity fuels innovation, and when we actively foster talent and build strong ecosystems, we accelerate transformation.

I leave this visit inspired ‚Äì by the region‚Äôs bold vision, its drive for AI-powered innovation, and the incredible people leading the way. Thank you to everyone who made this such a special visit, from Dr., Director at the UAE's AI Office and my fellow panelists Maitha Alnuimi,,and, as well as to,,and the entire regional team in UAE.
